title: I Make Questionable Choices Sometimes... - Linus Personal Rig Update Early 2023
description: Visit  and use offer code LTT for 10% off  Check out SignalRGB and sync all your RGB peripherals at   Linus hasn't gone all AMD in YEARS, but now that AM5 and RDNA 3 are here it's time for a change. There's just a few problems to sort out first, like the RAID card he HAD to use, and the custom loop that has already changed since he built it.  Discuss on the forum:   Buy a SABRENT Rocket Q 8TB NVMe PCIe M.2 SSD:   Buy an AMD Ryzen 9 7950X Processor:   Buy an ASRock X670E PG Lightning Motherboard:   Buy an EK-Quantum Velocity2 D-RGB AM5 Full Nickel Water Block:   Check out the EK-Quantum Vector RX 7900 XTX D-RGB AMD Radeon Edition:   Buy an ASRock Thunderbolt 4 AIC:   Buy an OWC 10G Ethernet PCIe Network Adapter Expansion Card:   Purchases made through some store links may provide some compensation to Linus Media Group.   GET MERCH:   LTX 2023 TICKETS AVAILABLE NOW:   GET EXCLUSIVE CONTENT ON FLOATPLANE:   SPONSORS, AFFILIATES, AND PARTNERS:   OUR WAN PODCAST GEAR:   FOLLOW US  ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Facebook:  Instagram:  TikTok:  Twitch:   MUSIC CREDIT --------------------------------------------------- Intro: Laszlo - Supernova Video Link:  iTunes Download Link:  Artist Link:   Outro: Approaching Nirvana - Sugar High Video Link:  Listen on Spotify:  Artist Link:   Intro animation by MBarek Abdelwassaa  Monitor And Keyboard by vadimmihalkevich / CC BY 4.0   Mechanical RGB Keyboard by BigBrotherECE / CC BY 4.0  Mouse Gamer free Model By Oscar Creativo / CC BY 4.0   CHAPTERS --------------------------------------------------- 0:00 Intro 1:35 The Raid Card 4:45 The CPU 6:10 The Motherboard 8:03 The CPU Cooler 9:50 The Memory 12:04 We Figured It Out 13:50 Water Cooling Montage 14:50 The GPU 15:55 The Thunderbolt Card 17:45 The Network Card 18:40 Will It Boot? 20:00 Conclusion 21:44 Outro

It just takes the 16 PCIe Gen4 lanes that come up through the slot here and then splits them up into four quad lane M.2 slots. The advantage of this approach is that it's economical, since you don't need an expensive controller on the board. But the disadvantage is that this card will only work on a motherboard that supports PCIe lane bifurcation, so the ability to take a slot and split it into more lower lane count slots. Now, some consumer motherboards support that, but it's most common on workstation and server boards. The other disadvantage is that because this is essentially just four independent drives, the only way to get them to operate together is using software RAID, meaning that you can't just take this card, plunk it in any system, and assume that it's going to boot up.
